intro: Randia sepium, commonly known as poisonwood or wild pepper, is a shrub native to the tropical regions of the Americas. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers followed by bright red berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Its roots and stems contain various alkaloids, which contribute to its medicinal and toxic properties. Randia sepium is often found in moist, shaded areas in tropical forests.
